hypothesis_content.title: FOMC Dovish Pivot Amplification in Perp Funding
hypothesis_content.statement: A confirmed dovish pivot by the Fed (e.g., shift to explicit easing bias, unexpected rate cut) will be initially met with a sharp, bullish price reaction in BTC. This catalyst will then be amplified in the derivatives market, causing an extreme and sustained shift to positive funding rates (> +50% annualized) across major perpetual swap exchanges for a period of 24-72 hours, creating a high-probability mean reversion short opportunity in BTC perps once funding peaks.
hypothesis_content.rationale: A major macro catalyst triggers a violent repositioning. The initial price move forces shorts to cover and entices leveraged longs, pushing funding to unsustainable extremes. The catalyst's initial effect is amplified by reflexive derivatives dynamics. Once the initial frenzy subsides, the extreme cost of holding longs (high funding) acts as a friction that catalyzes the *opposite* move—a liquidation of over-leveraged positions, making the funding rate itself a leading indicator for a short-term pullback.
entry_conditions: Catalyst: Fed statement/press conference interpreted as a clear dovish pivot by real-time news & market data (e.g., 2Y Treasury yield drops > 15 bps in 30 mins).
BTC rallies > 8% within 6 hours of the catalyst.
Aggregate perpetual swap funding rate across Binance, Bybit, OKX rises above +0.015% per 8h (+50%+ annualized) and sustains above that level for two consecutive 8h periods.
Entry: Short BTC-perp when the 8h funding rate prints its first decline from a local peak above +0.015%.

exit_conditions.take_profit: Funding rate mean-reverts to or below +0.005% per 8h
exit_conditions.stop_loss: BTC price makes a new 4h high above the entry candle

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: Falsified if, following 5 qualifying events, entering a short at peak funding yields a win rate < 60% for a 2% profit target, OR if funding remains elevated (>+0.01%) for more than 5 days without a significant price retracement (>3%).
